Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation2: A public protest begins to escalate, with tension rising between opposing groups
Story:
I woke up early, the hum of anticipation already in my chest. As a neighbor, I always tried to be considerate—never leaving my trash bins overflowing, always making sure the shared alley stayed clean. This morning, I noticed the bins were only half-full, but I knew some neighbors would want to toss in more before pickup. I hesitated, not wanting to drag them out too soon and take up space, but I also had to leave for my shift as a police officer.

At the station, the radio crackled with news of a protest growing downtown. As an officer, I was expected to enforce the law, keep the peace, and act decisively if things got out of hand. The tension in my chest grew. I thought about my neighbors, trusting me to respect our shared space, and the city, trusting me to maintain order. Both roles demanded my attention, but in such different ways. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of expectation pressing down as I laced up my boots, wondering which responsibility would have to give.
